item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: May 16
item.description: A performance by French acrobat artistes in Gurgaon, Haryana.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: French artists, part of an acrobatic musical production titled "Mana - A Cirque Spectacle," performing at a theater in the Kingdom of Dreams complex in Gurgaon, Haryana.

item.title: At War Blog: Battlefield Update: The Fight for Isolated Government Outposts in Northern Syria
item.description: As world leaders and commentators of every stripe have debated President Obama’s “red line,” there have been significant developments on the ground.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hassan Aboud and Abu Ayman, two commanders of Islamist fighting units.

item.title: At War Blog: For Troops Needing Psychological Help, Asking Can Be the Toughest Hurdle
item.description: A Marine veteran haunted by his service writes that the time has come to change the perception of post-traumatic stress disorder to allow greater honesty and healing.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ZACHARY BELL

item.title: Intruder Commits Suicide at Paris School
item.description: A man killed himself with a sawed-off shotgun in front of about a dozen children, according to preliminary police reports.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: India Ink: Three Cricket Players Arrested on Spot-Fixing Charges
item.description: The accused, representing the Rajasthan Royals team in the ongoing Indian Premier League season, allegedly struck a deal exceeding $70,000, police said.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: A demonstration in Bangalore, Karnataka, on Thursday against the alleged involvement of three cricketers in spot fixing.

item.title: Lens Blog: Andrea Gjestvang's Photos of Norway's Utoya Massacre Survivors
item.description: After the massacre in Utoya, Norway, in July 2011, Andrea Gjestvang sought to photograph the victims’ process of recovery, both physical and emotional.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES ESTRIN

item.title: Way of the World: Looking for Capitalism's Tipping Point
item.description: One of the most urgent questions in economics today is the connection between inequality and growth. That is because one of the big economic facts of our time is the surge in income disparity.
item.dc:creator: By CHRYSTIA FREELAND | REUTERS

item.title: Japan’s Economy Growing at 3.5% Annualized Rate
item.description: The solid pace of growth serves as early validation for Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s “three-arrowed” approach to the economy.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe spoke during a debate over the budget in parliament on Wednesday. The parliament later approved the budget.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Crisis of Masculinity? It’s the Economy, Stupid
item.description: A British legislator has bruised male pride by suggesting that a harsh economic climate has contributed to creating a brutalized macho culture among the nation’s men. Is she right?
item.category: Demos: A Network for Ideas & Action
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Fight Club: Fans of south London's Millwall soccer team clashed with police officers at a game at Wembley Stadium on April 13.

item.title: U.S. Military Advisers Among Dead in Explosion in Afghanistan
item.description: Six American military advisers were among those killed Thursday after a car bomb attack, Afghan officials said.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG and SANGAR RAHIMI
item.media:description: Afghan policemen stood guard on Thursday at the site of a suicide attack in Kabul.

item.title: Cyclone Fizzles as It Hits Bangladesh
item.description: Cyclone Mahasan weakened Thursday afternoon into a tropical storm and then dissipated, causing far less damage than had been feared, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: A volunteer walked along the Bay of Bengal coast on Thursday to evacuate people in Chittagong, Bangladesh.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Two Maos, and Two Views of China’s Past
item.description: Two men named Mao broadly represent two different political factions in China, and tensions between the camps have been growing.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: The portrait of Mao Zedong over Tiananmen Square in Beijing.

item.title: Ceiling Collapse at Cambodian Shoe Factory Kills 2
item.description: The factory had been making shoes for the Japanese manufacturer Asics.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:credit: Thomas Cristofoletti for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescuers searched for survivors at a small factory on the outskirts of the capital of Cambodia on Thursday.

item.title: E.U. Considers Emission Fines on Chinese and Indian Airlines
item.description: Ten carriers are accused of not providing required emissions data and not participating in a system that entitles airlines to emit greenhouse gases in European airspace.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: An Air China plane prepared to land at Beijing Capital International airport in September of last year.

item.title: India Ink: Delhi Gang Rape Suspect in ‘Critical Condition,’ Lawyer Says
item.description: Prison authorities dismiss allegations of the defendant being beaten and poisoned in Tihar Jail.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: Security guards manning the entrance to the Lok Nayak Jai Prakash Narayan hospital, New Delhi, where gang rape defendant Vinay Sharma is being treated.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Picasso Museum Reopening Is Delayed
item.description: The grand doors of the Musée National Picasso Paris will remain closed for another summer, extending a nearly four-year wait for its reopening.
item.dc:creator: By DOREEN CARVAJAL
item.media:description: Renovation is still in progress at the Picasso Museum in Paris.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: May 16
item.description: A breakthrough in cloning embryonic stem cells; the battle over Nelson Mandela’s legacy; smuggling KFC meals into Gaza; and a Lebanese artist finally gets her due.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:credit: Andri Tambunan for The New York Times
item.media:description: An instructor demonstrated a sewing machine at Indonesia’s national training center for seamstresses, which graduates 12,000 students a year.

item.title: India Ink: What Makes Narendra Modi a Middle-Class Hero?
item.description: Mr. Modi has won over the business community and the middle class with promises of encouraging private and foreign capital and focusing on fast growth rates.
item.dc:creator: By SAMBUDDHA MITRA MUSTAFI
item.media:description: Narendra Modi addressing an election rally in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, on Dec. 20, 2012.

item.title: India Ink: In Andhra, Maoist Rebels Pin Hopes on Memories of the Dead
item.description: Maoist leadership is facing a crisis, mainly because most of the top rebel leaders have either been killed or arrested in the last few years.
item.dc:creator: By RAHUL PANDITA
item.media:description: A police poster with photos of wanted Maoist leaders outside Birpur, Andhra Pradesh, the native place of Maoist leader Ganapathi, April 2010.

item.title: Ceiling Collapse at Shoe Factory in Cambodia Kills 2
item.description: The collapse in Phnom Penh killed at least two workers and underlined global worries about factory safety in poor countries.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:credit: Tang Chhin Sothy/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Rescuers in Cambodia searched for workers after a ceiling collapsed at a small factory outside the capital, Phnom Penh, on Thursday.

item.title: Bangladesh Orders 1 Million Evacuated as Cyclone Nears
item.description: Cyclone Mahasen was expected to hit the low-lying delta coast on Thursday evening, said the United Nations, which estimated 4.1 million people were at risk.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: E-Mails Show Jostling Over Benghazi ‘Talking Points’
item.description: Messages released by the White House showed fierce jostling between the Central Intelligence Agency and the State Department, and at the highest levels of the C.I.A., on talking points after the attacks in Libya.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER, ERIC SCHMITT and MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: The Lede: Raucous Cheers for Iran’s Wrestlers in Grand Central Terminal
item.description: Wrestling officials, diplomats and reporters filed video, photographs and text updates on a wrestling match between Iran and the United States in New York’s Grand Central Terminal on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Mandela Fades as South Africa Battles Over Legacy
item.description: As Nelson Mandela, 94, grows more fragile, the struggle in South Africa over how he will be remembered, and what he has to pass on, has become increasingly acrimonious.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN
item.media:description: Nelson Mandela’s family objected to images of President Jacob Zuma seated with him in April.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: When to Talk to Monsters
item.description: Assad’s a butcher, but a diplomatic deal is the best hope for Syria.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER R. HILL
